children: A 20-year-old woman undergoes an excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Hodgkin lymphoma. This diagnosis is established with a lymph node biopsy specimen showing Reed-Sternberg cells. These cells are large and are either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (“owl's eye” appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion–like nucleoli. Reed-Sternberg cells are usually derived from B lymphocytes. The absence of Reed–Sternberg cells has very high negative predictive value for Hodgkin disease.

objective.__html: Recognize a Reed-Sternberg cell to diagnose Hodgkin lymphoma.
